title: Asian-American representation in classrooms: The next battleground? | News for College Students | USA TODAY College
text:
SEND EMAIL 
A growing movement of Asian-American activists is adding a new voice into claims of systematic racism at campuses nationwide. 
From alleged racism against professors of color to calls for more Asian-American culture courses, the issues have resulted in protests and petitions at schools including Dartmouth College, Williams College, Cornell University, Stanford University and Northwestern University. 
Some campaigns for change have been successful — if long in coming. At Northwestern, where an Asian-American studies major will likely begin in the fall, the program has been agitated for since the 1990s, student newspaper The Daily Northwestern reports. 
Many others are still works in progress. 
At the end of May, 120 Dartmouth College students joined forces with the hashtag #fight4facultyofcolor on behalf of longtime English professor Aimee Bahng, who was denied tenure earlier that month despite receiving unanimous support from her department, The Dartmouth reports. 
From 2007 to 2012, according to a 2013 Dartmouth Ad Hoc Committee report , minority faculty left at a disproportionately higher rate than white faculty at Dartmouth. 
According to a change.org petition created by “concerned faculty” following Bahng’s tenure denial, her absence would be be a devastating blow to Asian-American studies at Dartmouth. The petition so far has amassed more than 3,600 signatures. Dartmouth students #fight4facultyofcolor (Photo: Kevin Bui) 
“Dr. Bahng’s tenure denial is one among many cases that demonstrate the proliferation of unconscious bias in the tenure review process at — but not limited to — institutions like Dartmouth,” the petition reads in part. “Dr. Bahng’s case offers another example of how Asian American women are among the least likely to be granted tenure, despite their excellence in research, teaching, and service.” 
“She’s an Asian-American woman that dares to challenge systems of power, systems of white supremacy (and) the administration itself,” says Kevin Bui, a rising senior at Dartmouth, about Bahng. “The environment was toxic for faculty of color.” 
That same day, the college released an “Action Plan for Inclusive Excellence” to the Dartmouth community, outlining plans to increase the number of tenured professors of color on campus, and a two-year fellowship in Asian-American studies. It is unclear whether the timing of the release was coincidental or if the plan was issued in response to the protests. 
“Pending approval by the Board of Trustees, Dartmouth will award tenure to at least four faculty of color this year,” Dartmouth spokesperson Diana Lawrence tells USA TODAY College. “Additionally, seven non-tenured professors of color will join Dartmouth’s Arts & Sciences faculty in the fall.” #Fight4FacultyOfColor bc my classes with these professors were the only classes I didn't have to educate my peers in pic.twitter.com/W6pzlhht0j 
— ps (@89pearls) May 10, 2016 
On April 28 at Williams College, the Asian American Students in Action (AASiA) group started a petition calling for Williams to hire another Asian-American professor at the college as well as establish an Asian-American studies concentration — noting that the call for such a program is now 25 years old. 
According to the petition, students are upset that the upcoming academic year will have only one course on Asian-American culture — an English class called “Reading Asian American Literature.” This class is limited to 15 students, and will be taught by the English department’s only tenured Asian-American professor, Dorothy Wang. 
“There is no institutional opposition at Williams to an Asian-American studies program,” Williams spokesperson Mary Dettloff tells USA TODAY College. “Faculty must propose a new curricular unit or program to the Curricular Planning Committee first and, so far, that has not happened.” 
Wang, however, thinks there’s more to it. 
“I’ve actually had white senior professors tell me ‘Asian Americans haven’t suffered as much as African Americans, so why should we study their literature?’” she says. “The perception is that Asian Americans either haven’t suffered, or that people really don’t want to discuss the U.S. racism against Asian Americans, (like) Chinese Exclusion (or) Japanese American internment. 
“The students are actually realizing that there’s not anyone there that can speak to this really crucial aspect of their history (and) American history, because Asian-American studies is a vital part of thinking of American history,” says Wang. “It’s not just a topic to serve Asian-American students.” 
Some students, like AASiA member Suiyi Tang, are growing tired of waiting for change. 
“(The administration tells us), ‘You’ll have to be patient, change comes slowly at an institution like this,’” says Tang. “And that’s something they’ve been telling us for 25 years.” Grace Li is a student at Harvard College and a USA TODAY College correspondent.
